Uberizacija mamilarskega bratstva in enotnosti
Za dobro organizirane kriminalne združbe meje na Balkanu že dolgo ne obstajajo. Če sploh kdaj so.
01 Nov 2019, 17:24 by Veso Stojanov



V Ljubljani se v povprečju porabi približno 50 kilogramov kokaina na leto.v povprečju porab



REUTERSPripadniki bavarske policije pred zaseženo pošiljko kokaina, vredno več milijonov evrov, ki je bila skrita v tovoru banan. FOTO: REUTERS



REUTERSSežiganje zaseženega kokaina FOTO: REUTERS



REUTERSNajbolj znani balkanski narko šef Darko Šarić med sojenjem v Beogradu. FOTO: REUTERS



Slovenska policija vse pogosteje odkriva nezakonite pošiljke mamil. FOTO: GUP



Darjan Ješovnik je bil na begu od leta 2011.


Od razpada Jugoslavije bo kmalu minilo trideset let, a dediščina več desetletij bivanja v skupni državi se še vedno pozna. Čeprav mnogi v novonastalih državah tega nočejo priznati in si zatiskajo oči, so nekatere povezave, ki seveda ne temeljijo na nekoč osnovni ideološki platformi bratstva in enotnosti, še vedno močne. Še najmanj na politični ravni, kjer sporov med balkanskimi državami nikakor ne zmanjka, precej bolje je na poslovnih, športnih, osebnih ravneh. Na enem področju pa se nove meje, ki so nastale med nekdanjimi republikami skupne države, še najmanj poznajo.
17 milijonov odraslih Evropejcev naj bi vsak dan uživalo kokain.
Gre za kriminalne združbe, kjer bratstvo in enotnost še vedno živita. Vezivo teh tesnih povezav seveda ni pretirana medsebojna ljubezen kriminalnih združb iz Srbije, s Kosova, iz Črne gore ali Hrvaške. Gre izključno za denar.


Pripadniki bavarske policije pred zaseženo pošiljko kokaina, vredno več milijonov evrov, ki je bila skrita v tovoru banan.FOTO: REUTERSREUTERS

Meja za kriminalce ni
Poznavalci razmer na Balkanu pravijo, da za dobro organizirane kriminalne združbe meja tu že dolgo ni, če so sploh kdaj obstajale. Prav poroznost meja, gospodarske razmere, revščina ter tudi posledice vojn v devetdesetih let so pripeljale do širitve kriminalnih združb in sodelovanja med njimi. Kot je pred časom za sarajevski dnevnik Dnevni Avaz izjavil nekdanji šef beograjske policije Marko Nicović, kriminalci niso obremenjeni niti z imeni in priimki niti z nacionalno pripadnostjo, religijo in drugimi elementi, zaradi katerih se Balkanci tako radi sprejo, in je zato sodelovanje med njimi bistveno lažje in učinkovitejše.Balkan je na stičišču Evrope in Azije oziroma Bližnjega vzhoda, zato mnoge kriminalne poti, od trgovine z mamili, prostitucije do prevoza ukradenih avtomobilov, trgovine z orožjem ali ljudmi, potekajo čez ozemlja nekdanjih jugoslovanskih republik, zaradi česar tudi naraščajo moč, vpliv in ugled kriminalnih združb.Njihovo dolgoletno sodelovanje ni ostalo neopaženo, saj njihove storitve že nekaj časa uporabljajo tudi večje svetovne mafijske in kriminalne združbe – južnoameriški karteli, ruska kriminalna združenja, mafija –, še posebno pri razpečevanju mamil. Tako so denimo že pred leti britanski kriminalisti ugotavljali, kako so albanske kriminalne združbe v sodelovanju s srbskimi kompanjoni povsem prevzele nadzor nad črnim trgom z mamili v Veliki Britaniji.
Aplikacija za dostavo mamil
Prav britanski policijski analitiki črnega trga z mamili so v javnost spravili analizo, po kateri naj bi albanske, srbske in hrvaške kriminalne skupine s pomočjo posebne aplikacije oblikovale nekakšno hitro dostavo mamil na dom. Potrebujemo le pameten telefon in aplikacijo, podobno Uberjevi, posebno šifro, in zavojček kokaina ali heroina je lahko pri naročniku že v desetih minutah. Če lahko prek interneta kupiš vse, tako rekoč od igle do lokomotive, zakaj ne bi še mamil, so najbrž razmišljali kreativci v kriminalnih združbah. Tako niso le znižali stroškov razpečevanja, temveč so tudi znatno zmanjšali izpostavljenost preprodajalcev mamil pred policijo in seveda povečali zaslužek vseh vpletenih v verigi.
350 kg kokaina morajo na evropski črni trg vsak dan spraviti kriminalne združbe.
Kot omenjajo nekateri britanski mediji, naj bi bili možgani celotne dejavnosti, ki Evropo oskrbuje z mamili, v dveh operativnih centrih. Eden naj bi bil na ozemlju Zahodnega Balkana, drugi pa v Severni Afriki, najverjetneje v Maroku. Balkanska kriminalna združenja mamila, v prvi vrsti gre za kokain, dobavljajo neposredno pri kolumbijskih mamilarskih kartelih. Kolumbijci ga z ladjami dostavijo v Evropo, na odprtem morju ga pretovorijo na hitre čolne, v tajnih laboratorijih pa po potrebi še dodelajo in obdelajo ter zapakirajo v priročne vrečke.Preprodaja mamila ne poteka več množično po ulicah in skrivnih kotičkih evropskih mest, ampak se preprosto naroči prek aplikacije, dostavijo pa ga posebni kurirji. In zaradi tovrstne modernizacije lahko dobijo zainteresirani mamila relativno hitro, v Londonu denimo tudi v desetih minutah. Po podatkih Evropskega centra za spremljanje drog in zasvojenosti z drogami tovrstna kurirska služba obstaja v Veliki Britaniji, Franciji, Belgiji in Španiji.


Sežiganje zaseženega kokainaFOTO: REUTERSREUTERS

Fantje z Balkana
Prav nezakonita trgovina s kokainom je postala v zadnjem času najdonosnejše kriminalno početje v Evropi in fantje z Balkana so vodilni v tem poslu, pravijo na evropskem uradu za droge. Zato se tudi povečuje število hujših kaznivih dejanj – zlasti z mamili povezani umori, s katerimi bratsko povezani balkanski fantje prevzemajo posle od tradicionalnih italijanskih mafijskih družin, saj so hkrati tudi njihova huda konkurenca. Ker kriminalne združbe brez posrednikov nabavljajo mamila pri dobaviteljih, občasno nastanejo nesporazumi, ki se vse pogosteje končajo bolj ali manj krvavo. Prav tovrstna konkurenca sili kriminalne združbe k čim boljšemu marketingu in izumljanju novih načinov in tehnologij prodaje mamil na črnem trgu.


Najbolj znani balkanski narko šef Darko Šarić med sojenjem v Beogradu. FOTO: REUTERSREUTERS

H konkurenci seveda spada tudi povečanje količin kokaina, ki pride na evropski trg. Spremenile so se tudi tihotapske poti. Če je še pred leti največ kokaina prišlo v Evropo skozi španske luke, so se v zadnjem času poti preusmerile proti francoskim, belgijskim in nemškim pristaniščem. Tudi druga niso preveč zapostavljena, kar kaže nedavno odkrita pošiljka več kot tone kokaina, vrednega prek 300 milijonov evrov, ki so ga romunski policisti zaplenili na nasedli ladji v ustju Donave.
Da so tudi slovenski kriminalci del združb balkanskih fantov, kaže nedavna aretacija Darjana Ješovnika, ki so ga sredi aprila aretirali v Srbiji pri prečkanju madžarsko-srbske meje. Štiriintridesetletnika je z mednarodno tiralico iskala Hrvaška od leta 2011, ko so deset oseb obtožili za poskus tihotapljenja kokaina, vrednega nekaj manj kot 13 milijonov evrov. Bil naj bi član kriminalne združbe, ki je pretihotapila najmanj 718 kg kokaina iz Južne Amerike v Španijo, na Hrvaško, v Slovenijo in na Nizozemsko. Mamila so zasegli v Španiji, Ješovnik, ki se ga je oprijel vzdevek kralj kokaina in naj bi po razpisu tiralice iz Ljubljane izpuhtel v neznano, pa naj bi bil kurir, ki je iz Amsterdama peljal denar za drogo.
Zasežejo ga le 15 odstotkov
Belgijski Antwerpen je v zadnjih letih postal najpomembnejše pristanišče za pretovor pošiljk kokaina v Evropi. Po podatkih evropskega urada za droge so ga tam leta 2017 zaplenili največ, in sicer 41 ton, medtem ko so ga v istem času v vsej Evropi zaplenili skoraj 71 ton. Opozarjajo, da je tihotapska pot prek velikih evropskih pristanišč lahko le vrh ledene gore, saj druge oblike tihotapljenja mamil, kot so na primer zasebna letala, ostajajo večinoma neodkrite. O tem pričajo zasežene količine kokaina, ki po ocenah strokovnjakov pomenijo le do 15 odstotkov vsega, ki najde pot do evropskega trga.Po nekaterih najnovejših podatkih naj bi vsaj 17 milijonov odraslih Evropejcev vsak dan uživalo beli prah. Da bi sledili povpraševanju, morajo kriminalne združbe na črni trg vsak dan spraviti najmanj 350 kilogramov kokaina. Kot primer navedimo, da ga samo v Švici porabijo več kot pet ton na leto.
Slovenija – kokainska oaza
Tudi v Sloveniji se poraba kokaina povečuje. Kot je pokazala lani objavljena analiza odpadnih voda 56 evropskih mest, ki jo je objavil evropski urad za droge – kmalu obljubljajo izsledke najnovejše raziskave –, spada Ljubljana med evropska mesta z največ kokaina v odpadnih vodah. Uvrstila se je na 11. mesto med 56 mesti v 19 državah, kjer so analizirali odpadne vode in tudi na ta način ugotavljali, koliko mamil uživajo prebivalci. Pri nas so našli 449,76 miligrama kokaina na tisoč ljudi na dan. Največ ga je sicer v odpadnih vodah Barcelone (965,2 miligrama na tisoč prebivalcev na dan), sledita Zürich (934,4) in Antwerpen (822,9). Najmanj so ga našli v finskem mestu Turku (4,7) in slovaškem Piestanyju (6,4).
Azijsko-balkansko-južnoameriška transverzala organiziranega kriminala ogroža območje nekdanje Jugoslavije, vse bolj pa tudi Slovenijo.
Po hitrem izračunu se v Ljubljani v povprečju porabi približno 50 kilogramov kokaina na leto, kar je sicer manj od Zagreba, kjer ga porabijo 63 kilogramov, a je glede na število prebivalcev seveda uporaba v Ljubljani dosti bolj razširjena.
Kriminal pregreva Balkan
O nevarnosti kriminalnih združb na območju Zahodnega Balkana je pred kratkim v Ljubljani govoril politični in vojaški analitik in dober poznavalec razmer Blagoje Grahovac iz Črne gore. Kot so o njegovem ljubljanskem predavanju zapisali na portalu delo.si, Grahovac meni, da lahko prav organizirani kriminal oziroma njegova azijsko-balkansko-južnoameriška transverzala znova pregreje ta prostor. Mednarodni organizirani kriminal je po njegovem mnenju eden od glavnih stranskih pojavov globalizacije in postaja prevladujoč geopolitični dejavnik v svetu. Ustavijo ga lahko le državne oblasti, če se tako odločijo, mafija pa skrbi, da se to ne zgodi – po potrebi tudi tako, da zmede in oslabi oblast s pomočjo nasilja oziroma terorizma, ki bo v prihodnosti zato vse bolj orodje organiziranega kriminala.


Darjan Ješovnik je bil na begu od leta 2011.

Za območje Zahodnega Balkana je značilno, da je bilo prizorišče nekaj velikodržavnih projektov na nacionalnih podlagah, katerih nosilci so za uresničenje svojih idej rekrutirali svoje mafije. Po vojnah v 90. letih 20. stoletja so nosilci teh politik odšli, a njihove mafije so ostale ter se celo povezale in postale mednarodne. Poleg tega je na Balkanu pristal velik del umazanega oziroma tajkunskega kapitala, ki je po razpadu Sovjetske zveze postal glavni izvozni artikel iz Rusije. Ta je namreč najprej potoval na Zahod, kjer so ga oprali, nato se je očiščen vrnil predvsem na Balkan.Azijsko-balkansko-južnoameriška transverzala organiziranega kriminala po oceni Grahovca ogroža celotno območje nekdanje Jugoslavije, vse bolj tudi Slovenijo, a kot najbolj ogroženo vidi Črno goro. Ves tuji kapital je tja sicer prišel z Zahoda, medtem ko so njegovi lastniki prav Rusi. Glavni problem pa ni v njih, ampak v domači politični eliti, ki je ta kapital pripeljala v državo in se vanj vgradila ...

The Uberization of the Mamillian Brotherhood and Unity
For well-organized criminal groups, the borders in the Balkans have long been absent. If ever they are.
01 Nov 2019, 16:24 by Veso Stojanov



In Ljubljana, an average of about 50 kilograms of cocaine is consumed per year



REUTERSBavarian police members have seized millions of euros worth of cocaine hidden in a cargo of bananas. PHOTO: REUTERS



REUTERSCocaine seizure burning PHOTO: REUTERS



REUTERSBest known Balkan narco boss Darko Saric during his trial in Belgrade. PHOTO: REUTERS



Increasingly, the Slovenian police are detecting illegal drug shipments. PHOTO: GUP



Darjan Yesovnik has been on the run since 2011.


Thirty years will soon pass since the breakup of Yugoslavia, but the legacy of several decades of residence in the common country is still known. Although many in the emerging world are reluctant to acknowledge this and turn a blind eye, some connections, which of course are not based on the once basic ideological platform of brotherhood and unity, are still strong. At least at the political level, where there are no conflicts between the Balkan countries, it is much better at the business, sports and personal levels. In one area, however, the new borders that have emerged between the former republics of the common state are least known.
17 million adult Europeans are expected to consume cocaine every day.
These are criminal organizations where fraternity and unity still live. The bond of these close ties, of course, is not the exaggerated love of criminal organizations from Serbia, Kosovo, Montenegro or Croatia. It's all about money.


Bavarian police members seized millions of euros worth of seized cocaine shipment hidden in a banana cargo.POTO: REUTERSREUTERS

There is no limit for criminals
Experts in the Balkans say that for well-organized criminal groups, borders have long been gone, if they ever existed. It is precisely the porosity of the borders, the economic situation, poverty and also the aftermath of the wars of the 1990s that led to the expansion of and cooperation between criminal organizations. Former Belgrade police chief Marko Nicovic told the Dnevni Avaz newspaper ahead of time that criminals are not burdened with names, nationality, religion and other elements that make the Balkans so happy, and therefore cooperation between them is essential The Balkans are at the intersection of Europe and Asia or the Middle East, so many criminal routes, from drug trafficking, prostitution to theft of stolen cars, arms or human trafficking, cross the territories of the former Yugoslav republics, causing them to grow in power, the influence and reputation of criminal organizations. Their longstanding involvement has not gone unnoticed, as their services have also been used for some time by major global mafia and criminal organizations - South American cartels, Russian criminal associations, the mafia - especially in drug trafficking. For example, many years ago British criminals found that Albanian criminal organizations, in co-operation with Serbian companions, had completely taken control of the black drug market in Britain.
A drug delivery app
It is the UK's black drug market analysts who have released to the public an analysis according to which Albanian, Serbian and Croatian crime groups are using a special application to form a kind of fast delivery of drugs to their homes. All we need is a smartphone and an Uber-like app, a special code, and a packet of cocaine or heroin can be with the customer within ten minutes. If you can buy everything online, so to speak, from needle to locomotive, why not lure it still, the creative thinkers in criminal organizations have probably been thinking. Not only did they reduce the cost of distribution, they also significantly reduced the exposure of drug traffickers to the police and, of course, increased the earnings of all those involved in the chain.
350 kg of cocaine must be brought to the European black market on a daily basis by criminal organizations.
As mentioned by some British media, the brain of the entire drug supplying activity in Europe is thought to be in two operational centers. One is believed to be in the Western Balkans and the other is in North Africa, most likely in Morocco. Balkan drug gangs, primarily cocaine, are shipped directly to Colombian drug cartels. Colombians ship it to Europe by ship, tranship it on the high seas by speedboat, and in secret laboratories, where necessary, refinish and process it and pack it in convenient bags. Drug trafficking is no longer carried out massively through the streets and secret corners of European cities, but simply orders through the app and is delivered by special couriers. And because of this kind of modernization, interested parties can get their drugs relatively quickly, even in ten minutes in London. According to the European Monitoring Center for Drugs and Drug Addiction, this kind of courier service exists in the United Kingdom, France, Belgium and Spain.


Burning seized cocainePhoto: REUTERSREUTERS

Boys from the Balkans
Illegal cocaine trafficking has become the most lucrative criminal activity in Europe lately, and the Balkan boys are leading this business, say the European Drugs Office. As a result, the number of serious crimes is increasing - especially the drug-related murders that the fraternity Balkan boys take on from traditional Italian mafia families, as they are also fiercely competitive. As criminal organizations procure narcotics from suppliers without intermediaries, there are occasional misunderstandings that more and more often end up more or less bloody. It is this kind of competition that forces criminal organizations to market as best they can and invent new ways and technologies of selling drugs on the black market.


The most famous Balkan narco boss Darko Saric during his trial in Belgrade. PHOTO: REUTERSREUTERS

Of course, competition also increases the amount of cocaine entering the European market. The smuggling routes have also changed. If most of the cocaine came to Europe through Spanish ports years ago, routes have recently shifted to French, Belgian and German ports. Others are not too neglected either, as indicated by a recently discovered shipment of more than 300m euros worth of cocaine seized by Romanian police officers on a stranded ship in the Danube estuary.
The recent arrest of Darjan Yesovnik, who was arrested in Serbia in crossing the Hungarian-Serbian border in mid-April, shows that Slovenian criminals are also part of the Balkan boys' associations. The 24-year-old has been wanted by an international prosecutor since 2011, when ten people were accused of trying to smuggle cocaine worth just under € 13 million. He was allegedly a member of a criminal organization that smuggled at least 718 kg of cocaine from South America to Spain, Croatia, Slovenia and the Netherlands. The drugs were seized in Spain, and Yeshovnik, nicknamed the king of cocaine and allegedly burglarized after being called by a Ljubljana tyrant, was allegedly a courier who was carrying drugs from Amsterdam.
It is only seized by 15 percent
Belgium's Antwerp has become the most important port for transhipment of cocaine in Europe in recent years. According to the European Narcotics Bureau, it was seized the most in 2017, at 41 tonnes, while at the same time nearly 71 tonnes were seized throughout Europe. They warn that the smuggling route through major European ports can only be the tip of the iceberg, as other forms of drug smuggling, such as private jets, remain largely undiscovered. Seizures of cocaine testify to this, which experts estimate accounts for only up to 15 per cent of everything that finds its way into the European market. According to some recent data, at least 17 million adult Europeans are expected to consume white powder every day. To keep up with the demand, criminal organizations have to bring at least 350 pounds of cocaine to the black market every day. As an example, it is used in Switzerland alone for more than five tonnes per year.
Slovenia - Cocaine Oasis
Cocaine consumption in Slovenia is also increasing. The wastewater analysis of 56 cities across Europe, published by the European Bureau of Drugs - promising results from the latest research - showed last year that Ljubljana is among the European cities with the most cocaine in wastewater. It was ranked 11th out of 56 cities in 19 countries, where wastewater was analyzed to determine how much drugs are consumed by residents. We found 449.76 milligrams of cocaine per thousand people a day. It is mostly found in the wastewater of Barcelona (965.2 milligrams per thousand inhabitants per day), followed by Zurich (934.4) and Antwerp (822.9). It was the least found in the Finnish city of Turku (4.7) and the Slovak Piestany (6.4).
The Asian-Balkan-South American organized crime transversal threatens the territory of the former Yugoslavia, and increasingly Slovenia.
According to a quick calculation, Ljubljana consumes on average about 50 kilograms of cocaine per year, which is less than Zagreb, where it consumes 63 kilograms, but of course the use is much more widespread in Ljubljana.
Crime overheats the Balkans
A political and military analyst and a good expert on the situation of Montenegro, Blagoje Grahovac, spoke recently in Ljubljana about the danger of criminal organizations in the Western Balkans. As Grahovac wrote about his Ljubljana lecture on the job.si portal, it is precisely organized crime, or his Asian-Balkan-South American transversals, that can reheat this space. According to him, international organized crime is one of the major side effects of globalization and is becoming a dominant geopolitical factor in the world. It can only be stopped by state authorities if they choose to do so, and the mafia makes sure that this does not happen - if necessary, by confusing and weakening power through violence or terrorism, which will therefore become an increasingly organized crime tool in the future.

After the wars of the 1990s, the policy makers left, but their mafias remained, and even connected and became international. In addition, much of the dirty or tycoon capital landed in the Balkans, which became the main export item from Russia after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Namely, he first traveled to the West, where he was washed, and then cleaned himself, returned mainly to the Balkans. goro. All foreign capital came from the West, while its owners were Russians. The main problem, however, is not in them, but in the domestic political elite that brought this capital into the country and built into it ...
